<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 650, 91]]<|/det|> In this experiment you will investigate the loading of a metre rule. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 571, 122]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 133, 764, 285]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 303, 509, 322]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 333, 875, 383]]<|/det|> You are provided with a metre rule that is attached at one end to the bench. The other end is supported by a forcemeter. Do not change the position of the forcemeter or move the end of the rule that is attached to the bench. You are also provided with a range of masses. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 396, 146, 415]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 396, 873, 415]]<|/det|> Without placing a mass on the rule, record in Table 1.1 the reading \(F\) on the forcemeter. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 427, 146, 445]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 427, 875, 460]]<|/det|> Place a \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass on the rule at the \(50.0\mathrm{cm}\) mark shown in Fig. 1.1. Record in the table the value of the mass \(m\) and the reading \(F\) on the forcemeter. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 473, 144, 491]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 473, 672, 491]]<|/det|> Repeat step (b) using masses of \(200\mathrm{g}, 300\mathrm{g}, 400\mathrm{g}\) and \(500\mathrm{g}\). <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 510, 517, 528]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 541, 728, 749]]<|/det|>
\(m/g\)\(F/N\)
0

<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 653, 92]]<|/det|>
In this experiment you will investigate the rate of cooling of water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 876, 139]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 2.1. You are provided with a supply of water.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[344, 151, 599, 375]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 396, 509, 416]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 428, 144, 447]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 428, 509, 448]]<|/det|>
Measure and record room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[473, 459, 876, 479]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 490, 146, 508]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 489, 875, 526]]<|/det|>
Pour hot water into the test-tube until it is about two thirds full of water. Place the thermometer in the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 536, 144, 555]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 536, 175, 555]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 536, 875, 586]]<|/det|>
When the thermometer reading stops rising, measure the temperature \(\theta\) of the water in the test-tube and immediately start the stopclock. Record \(\theta\) in Table 2.1 at time \(t = 0s\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 599, 180, 617]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 599, 875, 635]]<|/det|>
Record in the table the time \(t\) and the temperature \(\theta\) of the water every 30s until you have a total of seven readings.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 645, 146, 663]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 645, 875, 695]]<|/det|>
Remove the thermometer and pour away the water from the test-tube. Wrap the cotton wool round the test-tube and secure it with the elastic bands. Repeat the steps in **(b)** and **(c)**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 707, 144, 725]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 707, 695, 725]]<|/det|>
Complete the time and temperature column headings in the table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 808, 109]]<|/det|> In this experiment you will investigate the resistance of a wire in different arrangements. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 554, 138]]<|/det|> The circuit shown in Fig. 3.1 has been set up for you. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 152, 688, 365]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 375, 509, 394]]<|/det|> [Fig. 3.1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 405, 144, 424]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 405, 185, 424]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 405, 878, 440]]<|/det|> Switch on. Measure and record in Table 3.1 the current \(I\) in the circuit and the p.d. \(V\) across the section of wire \(\mathbf{AB}\). Switch off. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 452, 181, 470]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 452, 576, 471]]<|/det|> Record in the table the length \(l\) of the wire \(\mathbf{AB}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 483, 178, 502]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 483, 777, 502]]<|/det|> Calculate the resistance \(R\) of the section of wire \(\mathbf{AB}\) using the equation <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 508, 509, 536]]<|/det|> \[R = \frac{V}{I}.\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 578, 480, 597]]<|/det|> Record this value of \(R\) in the table. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 610, 178, 628]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 610, 554, 628]]<|/det|> Complete the column headings in the table. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 641, 181, 660]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 641, 870, 660]]<|/det|> Repeat steps (i) – (iii) with the voltmeter connected across section \(\mathbf{AC}\) of the wire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 672, 181, 691]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 672, 870, 691]]<|/det|> Repeat steps (i) – (iii) with the voltmeter connected across section \(\mathbf{AD}\) of the wire. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 718, 517, 737]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 749, 875, 885]]<|/det|>
voltmeter
connected
across		\(l/\)\(l/\)\(V/\)\(R/\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 823, 92]]<|/det|>
In this experiment you will investigate the refraction of light through a transparent block

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 571, 123]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[242, 133, 705, 603]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 616, 509, 635]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 647, 146, 666]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 647, 875, 698]]<|/det|>
Place the transparent block, largest face down, on the sheet of plain paper supplied. The block should be approximately in the middle of the paper. Draw and label the outline ABCD of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 710, 146, 728]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 710, 875, 745]]<|/det|>
Remove the block and draw the normal \(\mathbf{NN}'\) to side \(\mathbf{AB}\) so that the normal is \(2.0 \text{cm}\) from \(\mathbf{A}\). Label the point \(\mathbf{F}\) where \(\mathbf{NN}'\) crosses \(\mathbf{AB}\) and \(\mathbf{G}\) where it crosses \(\mathbf{DC}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 756, 144, 774]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 756, 740, 775]]<|/det|>
Draw the line \(\mathbf{EF}\) at an angle of \(30^{\circ}\) to the normal, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 787, 134, 806]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 787, 435, 806]]<|/det|>
Place the paper on the pin board.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 818, 144, 836]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 817, 628, 836]]<|/det|>
Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line \(\mathbf{EF}\) as shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 848, 144, 866]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 848, 875, 930]]<|/det|>
Replace the block and observe the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through side \(\mathbf{CD}\) of the block so that the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) appear one behind the other. Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) between your eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_3\) , \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) , seen through the block, appear one behind the other. Mark and label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) , \(\mathsf{P}_2\) , \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) . Remove the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(g)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 813, 107]]<|/det|>
Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Continue the line until it meets \(\mathbf{CB}\) this point \(\mathbf{H}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 119, 146, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(h)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 549, 139]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the length \(a\) of the line \(\mathbf{GH}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 149, 876, 170]]<|/det|>
<form>a = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 180, 141, 200]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 301, 200]]<|/det|>
Draw the line \(\mathbf{HF}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 211, 141, 231]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 210, 547, 231]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 467, 875, 533]]<|/det|>
This experiment can be carried out using a ray of light, produced by a ray box, instead of by using optical pins. A student suggests that the ray box method will be more accurate. Assuming that the experiment is carried out with care, suggest one possible cause of inaccuracy using the optical pin method and one using the ray box method.
